sen.j: 談山神社（たんざんじんじゃ）は、奈良県桜井市の多武峰（とうのみね）にある神社。
sen.e: Tanzan-jinja Shrine is a shrine located in Tonomine, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.
Tanzan-jinja Shrine is a shrine located in Mt. Tonomine, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.
Tanzan-jinja Shrine is a shrine located in Mt. Tonomine, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 祭神は、藤原鎌足（談山大明神・談山権現）。
sen.e: Its enshrined deity is FUJIWARA no Kamatari (Danzan Daimyojin, Danzan Gongen).
Its enshrined deity is FUJIWARA no Kamatari (Danzan Daimyojin, Danzan Gongen).
Its enshrined deity is FUJIWARA no Kamatari (Danzan Daimyojin, Danzan Gongen).

sen.j: サクラとカエデの名所である。
sen.e: It is a place well known for beautiful cherry blossoms and maple tree leaves.
It is a place well known for beautiful cherry blossoms and maple tree leaves.
It is a place well known for beautiful cherry blossoms and maple tree leaves.

sen.j: 神仏分離以前は、寺院であり、多武峯寺という名称であった。
sen.e: It was once a temple named Tonomine temple before the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism.
It was once a temple named Tonomine temple before the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism.
It was once a temple named Tonomine temple before the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に成立した寺伝によると、藤原氏の祖である藤原鎌足の死後の天武天皇7年（678年）、長男で僧の定恵が唐からの帰国後に、父の墓を摂津国安威の地（参照：阿武山古墳）から大和国のこの地に移し、十三重塔を造立したのが発祥である。
sen.e: Its temple history written in Kamakura period describes the origin of the shine: after the founder of the Fujiwara clan, FUJIWARA no Kamatari, died, a monk and his eldest son Joe came back to Japan from China (Tang Dynasty) and moved his father's tomb from Ai, Settsu Province (see Abuyama Tumulus) to Yamato-no-kuni, where he had Jusanjunoto (Thirteen-storied pagoda) erected in 678.

Its temple history written in Kamakura period describes the origin of the shine, and according to it, after the death of the founder of the Fujiwara clan, FUJIWARA no Kamatari, a monk and his elder son Joe came back to Japan from China (Tang Dynasty) and moved his father's tomb from Ai, Settsu Province (see Abuyama Tumulus) to Yamato Province, where he erected Jusanjunoto (Thirteen-storied pagoda) in 678.
sen.cmt: he had Jusanjunoto (Thirteen-storied pagoda) erected→ he erected Jusanjunoto (Thirteen-storied pagoda)
sen.e: Its temple history written in Kamakura period describes the origin of the shine, and according to it, after the death of the founder of the Fujiwara clan, FUJIWARA no Kamatari, a monk and his elder son Joe came back to Japan from China (Tang Dynasty) and moved his father's tomb from Ai, Settsu Province (see Abuyama Tumulus) to Yamato Province, where he erected Jusanjunoto (Thirteen-storied pagoda) in 678.

sen.j: 天武天皇9年（680年）に講堂（現在の神社建築）が創建され、そこを妙楽寺と号した。
sen.e: In 680, Kodo Hall (now in shrine architecture) was build and named Myoraku-ji Temple.
In 680, Kodo Hall (existent shrine architecture) was build and named Myoraku-ji Temple.
In 680, Kodo Hall (existent shrine architecture) was build and named Myoraku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 大宝 (日本)元年（701年）、十三重塔の東に鎌足の木像を安置する祠堂（現在の神社建築）が建立され、聖霊院と号した。
sen.e: In 701, Shido (a hall dedicated to the souls of ancestors) (now in shrine architecture) was built beside the Jusanjunoto to enshrine a wooden image of Kamatari and was called Shoryoin.
In 701, Shido (a hall dedicated to the souls of ancestors) (existent shrine architecture) was built beside the Jusanjunoto to enshrine a wooden image of Kamatari and was called Shoryoin.
In 701, Shido (a hall dedicated to the souls of ancestors) (existent shrine architecture) was built beside the Jusanjunoto to enshrine a wooden image of Kamatari and was called Shoryoin.

sen.j: 談山の名の由来は、藤原鎌足と天智天皇が、大化元年（645年）5月に大化の改新の談合をこの多武峰にて行い、後に「談い山（かたらいやま）」「談所ヶ森」と呼んだことによるとされる。
sen.e: It is believed that the name Tanzan came from a meeting held by FUJIWARA no Kamatari and the Emperor Tenchi in Tonomine in May 645 to discuss the Taika Reforms and that the mountain was later called "kataraiyama" or "dansho no mori."

It is believed that the name Tanzan (mountain of negotiation) came from an episode that FUJIWARA no Kamatari and Emperor Tenchi held a meeting in May 645 in Mt. Tonomine to discuss the Taika Reforms and, and later the mountain came to be called "kataraiyama" (mountain of chat) or "dansho no mori" (woods of consultation).
sen.cmt: 談山神社と「談い山（かたらいやま）」「談所ヶ森」との関連がわかるよう説明を加えました。NC_check: the whole sentence (as I changed the structure)
sen.e: It is believed that the name Tanzan (mountain of negotiation) came from an episode that FUJIWARA no Kamatari and Emperor Tenchi held a meeting in May 645 in Mt. Tonomine to discuss the Taika Reforms and, and later the mountain came to be called "kataraiyama" (mountain of chat) or "dansho no mori" (woods of consultation).

sen.j: 平安時代には藤原高光が出家後に入山、増賀上人を招聘するなど、藤原氏の繁栄と共に発展を遂げた。
sen.e: In the Heian period, the temple developed along with the prosperity of the Fujiwara clan, as is shown in the entry of the mountain by FUJIWARA no Takamitsu after his priesthood and the invitation of Zoga shonin.

In the Heian period, the temple developed along with the prosperity of the Fujiwara clan, as is shown in such episodes as the ascetic stay of FUJIWARA no Takamitsu at the temple after he had entered into priesthood and the temple's invitation to a holy priest Zoga shonin.
sen.cmt: NC_check: the sentence beginning with 'as is shown in…,' especially, the usage of 'as is shown in' is OK?
sen.e: In the Heian period, the temple developed along with the prosperity of the Fujiwara clan, as is shown in such episodes as the ascetic stay of FUJIWARA no Takamitsu at the temple after he had entered into priesthood and the temple's invitation to a holy priest Zoga shonin.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には曹洞宗本山永平寺の二世、孤雲懐奘（大和尚）が参学した。
sen.e: In the Kamakukra period, Koun Ejo (Daiosho (Great Osho)), who later became the second chief priest of Eihei-ji Temple of the Soto Zen sect, learned the Buddhism here.
In the Kamakukra period, Koun Ejo (Daiosho [Great Osho]), who later became the second chief priest of Eihei-ji Temple of the Soto Zen sect, learned the Buddhism here.
In the Kamakukra period, Koun Ejo (Daiosho [Great Osho]), who later became the second chief priest of Eihei-ji Temple of the Soto Zen sect, learned the Buddhism here.

sen.j: 平安時代に天台僧・増賀を迎えたことから、同じ大和国の藤原氏縁の寺院でありながら、宗派の違う興福寺とは争いが絶えなかった。
sen.e: After the temple invited a tendai priest Zoga in the Heian period, it always had arguments with Kofuku-ji Temple, which were common in connection with the Fujiwara clan of Yamato-no-kuni but different in the sect.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Since the temple invited Zoga, who was a priest of Tendai sect, in the Heian period, it was never free from disputes with Kofuku-ji Temple, which were common in connection with the Fujiwara clan of Yamato-no-kuni but different in the sect.
sen.cmt: it always had arguments →it was never free from disputesNC_check: Which is correct, 'in the sect' or 'in sect' (without article)?
sen.e: Since the temple invited Zoga, who was a priest of Tendai sect, in the Heian period, it was never free from disputes with Kofuku-ji Temple, which were common in connection with the Fujiwara clan of Yamato-no-kuni but different in the sect.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代から室町時代にかけてはたびたび領地などを巡り争論を繰り広げていた。
sen.e: From the Kamakura period through the Muromachi period, they frequently had arguments over the territory.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: From the Kamakura period through the Muromachi period, the two temples frequently had disputes over the territory.
From the Kamakura period through the Muromachi period, the two temples frequently had disputes over the territory.

sen.j: 1585年（天正13）、豊臣秀吉により、郡山城下に移すことを厳命され破却、遷座。
sen.e: In 1585, after Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI strictly ordered it to move to an area under control of Koriyama-jo Castle, it was destroyed and transferred.
In 1585, after Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI issued a strict order to relocate the temple to an area under control of Koriyama-jo Castle, its buildings were destroyed and transferred.
sen.cmt: strictly ordered it to move→issued a strict order to relocate the templeit was →its buildings were
sen.e: In 1585, after Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI issued a strict order to relocate the temple to an area under control of Koriyama-jo Castle, its buildings were destroyed and transferred.

sen.j: 1590年（天正18）年に、帰山を許された。
sen.e: In 1590, it was allowed to go back to the mountain.
In 1590, it was allowed to go back to the mountain.
In 1590, it was allowed to go back to the mountain.

sen.j: 徳川家康により復興。
sen.e: It revived by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
It was reconstructed by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
It was reconstructed by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 近世の朱印領は3000石余である。
sen.e: In the early-modern times, it had shuinryo of 541.17 cubic meters.
In the early-modern times, it had shuinryo with a production of more than 3,000 koku crop yield.
sen.cmt: revived→was reconstructed541.17 cubic meters→more than 3,000 koku crop yield
sen.e: In the early-modern times, it had shuinryo with a production of more than 3,000 koku crop yield.

sen.j: 1869年（明治2）に僧徒が還俗。
sen.e: In 1869, soto (priests) returned to secular life.
In 1869, soto (Buddhist priests) were ordered to return to secular life.
sen.cmt: (priests) returned→ (Buddhist priests) were ordered to return
sen.e: In 1869, soto (Buddhist priests) were ordered to return to secular life.

sen.j: 談山神社と改称された。
sen.e: It changed its name to Tanzan-jinja Shrine.
It changed its name to Tanzan-jinja Shrine.
It changed its name to Tanzan-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 仏教伽藍は現代も談山神社境内に見ることができ、登拝者も後を絶たない。
sen.e: There is no end to the number of people who climb the mountain and visit Tanzan-jinja Shrine whose Buddhist Garan is still found in its precinct.
There is no end to the number of people who climb the mountain and visit Tanzan-jinja Shrine whose Buddhist Garan is still found in its precinct.
There is no end to the number of people who climb the mountain and visit Tanzan-jinja Shrine whose Buddhist Garan is still found in its precinct.

sen.j: 明治の廃仏毀釈の際に寺を廃し神社のみとなったが、建物は寺院建築をそのまま使用しているため、独特の雰囲気を残している。
sen.e: Although Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism) in the Meiji era forced it to abolish Buddhism and remain only as a shrine, it has used its temple architecture and remained a unique atmosphere.

Although Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism) in the Meiji period forced it to eliminate the Buddhist institution and remain only as a shrine, it has continued using its Buddhist temple architecture and conserved a unique atmosphere.
sen.cmt: Meiji era→ Meiji period abolish Buddhism →eliminate the Buddhist institutionhas used→continued using remained → conserved
sen.e: Although Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism) in the Meiji period forced it to eliminate the Buddhist institution and remain only as a shrine, it has continued using its Buddhist temple architecture and conserved a unique atmosphere.

sen.j: 談山神社から御破裂山への山道があり、その奥に藤原鎌足の墓所といわれる陵がある。
sen.e: A mausoleum believed to be the tomb for FUJIWARA no Kamatari is behind a mountain pass that goes from Tanzan-jinja Shrine to Goharetu-zan Mountain.
A mausoleum believed to be the tomb of FUJIWARA no Kamatari is behind a mountain pass that goes from Tanzan-jinja Shrine to Goharetsu-zan Mountain.
sen.cmt: tomb for FUJIWARA no Kamatari →tomb of FUJIWARA no KamatariGoharetu→Goharetsu
sen.e: A mausoleum believed to be the tomb of FUJIWARA no Kamatari is behind a mountain pass that goes from Tanzan-jinja Shrine to Goharetsu-zan Mountain.

sen.j: 談山神社から、少し歩いたところに藤原鎌足の次男、淡海公（藤原不比等）の墓といわれる石塔がある。
sen.e: There are a stone pagoda believed to be the tomb for the second son of FUJIWARA no Kamatari, Tankaiko (a posthumous title of FUJIWARA no Fusasaki) within a short walk from Tanzan-jinja Shrine.
There are a stone pagoda believed to be the tomb for the second son of FUJIWARA no Kamatari, Tankaiko (a posthumous title of FUJIWARA no Fuhito) within a short walk from Tanzan-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 藤原不比等：FUJIWARA no Fusasaki→FUJIWARA no Fuhito
sen.e: There are a stone pagoda believed to be the tomb for the second son of FUJIWARA no Kamatari, Tankaiko (a posthumous title of FUJIWARA no Fuhito) within a short walk from Tanzan-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 尚、拝殿や十三重塔は戦前に何度か日本銀行券の図案に採用された事がある。
sen.e: For reference, its haiden (a hall of worship) and Jusanjunoto were adopted as a design on Bank of Japan notes a few times before the war (in prewar times).
For reference, images of its haiden (a hall of worship) and Jusanjunoto were adopted on Bank of Japan notes a few times before the war (in prewar times).
sen.cmt: its haiden (a hall of worship) and Jusanjunoto were adopted as a design →images of its haiden (a hall of worship) and Jusanjunoto were adopted
sen.e: For reference, images of its haiden (a hall of worship) and Jusanjunoto were adopted on Bank of Japan notes a few times before the war (in prewar times).

sen.j: 粟原寺三重塔伏鉢（おうばらでらさんじゅうのとうふくばち）‐桜井市粟原（談山神社の北東方向）の山中に跡が残る粟原寺の遺物である。
sen.e: Three-storied fukubachi (inverted bowl-shaped part of a pagoda finial) in Obara-dera Temple: it is remains of Obara-dera Temple found in mountains in Obara Sakurai City (northeast of Tanzan-jinja Shrine)

Fukubachi (inverted bowl-shaped base of a pagoda finial) of Obara-dera Temple Sanjunoto (three-storied pagoda): an artifact of Obara-dera Temple, whose ruin is found in the mountains in Obara, Sakurai City (northeast of Tanzan-jinja Shrine)
sen.cmt: 粟原寺三重塔伏鉢（おうばらでらさんじゅうのとうふくばち）：Fukubachi (inverted bowl-shaped base of a pagoda finial) of Obara-dera Temple Sanjunoto (three-storied pagoda)としました。
sen.e: Fukubachi (inverted bowl-shaped base of a pagoda finial) of Obara-dera Temple Sanjunoto (three-storied pagoda): an artifact of Obara-dera Temple, whose ruin is found in the mountains in Obara, Sakurai City (northeast of Tanzan-jinja Shrine)

sen.j: 「伏鉢」とは、三重塔、五重塔などの最上部に立つ「相輪」の部材の一つ。
sen.e: "Fukubachi" refers to a part of "Sorin (metal pinnacle)" on the top of three- or five-storied pagodas.
"Fukubachi" refers to a part of "Sorin (metal pinnacle)" on the top of three- or five-storied pagodas.
"Fukubachi" refers to a part of "Sorin (metal pinnacle)" on the top of three- or five-storied pagodas.

sen.j: 銅製で、和銅8年（715年）の年号を含む刻銘がある。
sen.e: It is made of copper and bears an inscription including the year of 715.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is made of copper and bears an inscription including the year of 715.
It is made of copper and bears an inscription including the year of 715.

sen.j: 中臣大島（なかとみのあそんおおしま）が草壁皇子のために発願したという粟原寺の由緒が書かれている。
sen.e: It describes the origin of Obara-dera Temple that NAKATOMI no Oshima founded it for Prince Kusakabe with an imperial order.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It describes the origin of Obara-dera Temple that NAKATOMI no Ason Oshima founded it for Prince Kusakabe with an imperial order.
sen.cmt: 中臣大島（なかとみのあそんおおしま）の読み方を確認してください。 NAKATOMI no Ason Oshimaとしてあります。
sen.e: It describes the origin of Obara-dera Temple that NAKATOMI no Ason Oshima founded it for Prince Kusakabe with an imperial order.

sen.j: 「工芸品」ではなく「考古資料」の部の国宝に指定されている。
sen.e: It is designated as a national treasure not in the "craft products" section but in "archaeological materials" section.
It is designated as a national treasure not in the category of 'craft' but in the category of 'archaeological materials.'
It is designated as a national treasure not in the category of 'craft' but in the category of 'archaeological materials.'

sen.j: 奈良国立博物館に寄託。
sen.e: It has been deposited in Nara National Museum.
It is deposited in Nara National Museum.
It is deposited in Nara National Museum.
